title: Bill Belichick explains ‘simple’ reason why he decided to ban Patriots scout at UNC
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick banned a Patriots scout from UNC practices, citing past treatment at Patriots' facilities as the reason.
Belichick and the UNC football management informed Patriots scouts of the ban shortly before a scheduled visit in August.
Although Belichick left the Patriots in 2023, tensions with owner Robert Kraft and the organization have persisted.

title: Patriots vs. Raiders live updates: Will New England start Mike Vrabel era with a win?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots begin their 2025 season against the Raiders at Gillette Stadium; kickoff at 1 p.m.
Mike Vrabel leads New England in his first regular-season game as head coach.
Patriots introduce four new starters on the offensive line including rookie LT Will Campbell.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Ken Casey of Dropkick Murphys criticized Donald Trump during their Seisiun festival performance in Boston.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a Marine veteran and oyster farmer, running against Sen. Susan Collins in Maine.
The endorsement highlights Platner's campaign against Trumpism and his willingness to challenge the Democratic establishment.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Mayor Wu's office-residential conversion program's first project completed, converting five office floors into 15 apartments at 281 Franklin St.
The program aims to convert 700,000 square feet of office space into over 800 residential units, with a $15 million state funding boost.
Concerns remain about high office vacancy rates; mayoral candidate Josh Kraft calls for broader, creative public-private partnership strategies.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Disciplinary cases at Harvard tripled during 2023-2024 due to pro-Palestine protests, reports The Harvard Crimson.
58 students were placed on probation mainly for a November 2023 occupation and April 2024 encampment.
Five suspended students had penalties reduced to probation after criticism of the university's disciplinary actions.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: Day 1 of the Seisiún Irish music festival took place at Suffolk Downs despite severe weather conditions.
Performers included Dropkick Murphys, The Hold Steady, and The Scratch, with attendees braving rain delays.
Festival-goers enjoyed music alongside Irish cultural elements, such as Guinness and Irish flag attire.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective 'And Another Thing' is on display at Bates College Museum of Art in Maine until Oct. 11.
The exhibit features 149 original artworks from Steadman's 60-year career, including political cartoons and collaborations with Hunter S. Thompson.
Steadman recounts a 1970 incident in Newport, where he and Thompson attempted to vandalize a yacht while under the influence.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: About 40,000 adult SNAP recipients in Greater Boston are at risk of losing benefits under Trump's new bill.
The new bill may cause 9,600 legally present immigrants in Massachusetts to lose SNAP eligibility.
Massachusetts will cover 75% of SNAP administration costs, increasing state expenses by $58 million in fiscal year 2025.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: The Revolution's playoff hopes diminished significantly after a 3-2 loss to Chicago Fire.
New England struggled early, conceding two quick goals in the first 10 minutes of the match.
Coach Caleb Porter accepted responsibility for the loss, acknowledging tactical errors and poor results.

title: Boston’s preliminary election is almost here. Here’s who will be on the ballot
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's preliminary election is scheduled for Sept. 9, narrowing candidates for mayor and City Council before the general election.
Top two mayoral candidates advance to Nov. 4 election; ten at-large City Council candidates compete for four spots.
Mayor Michelle Wu and challenger Josh Kraft are prominent contenders, differing on issues like housing and public transportation.
